@tqchen hey could you help review this again at your convenience? Rebasing many times seems painful to me.

I checked the ci image locally and the test does not run. You can try to reproduce locally via
- docker/build.sh ci_cpu bash
- docker/bash.sh ci_cpu 
   - Type cargo and run the test scripts.

The main reason is that default rustup installs the env only for the current user(which is root). And docker/bash.sh script will actually enter an env that is the same as the user who typed the command. And in that case /root/.cargo is not accessible.

Seems some customized configuration is necessary to make sure rust installation works for all users in the system. @nhynes can you try to do some tests locally and send an updated version of script that works? Also the mod of test/script/task_rust.sh need to be changed to executable
The changes LGTM, let us wait the CI and then merge it in

Some further comment. Note that you can verify locally by running the script
```bash
docker/bash.sh tvmai/ci-cpu
./tests/scripts/task_rust.sh
```

Sorry about that. It's 100% for sure actually fixed now.

Also, there's an independent PR that will make rust builds way faster (#1859). That one can be merged after this one since sccache transparently makes things better.

OK. The reason the `allocate` was put into outer most scope is because the code only call `PlanNewScope` for `ForType::Parallel`:
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/7bafca4e550d451925abfa2f0bc897d080cbbf35/src/pass/storage_rewrite.cc#L754-L757

Is it still the case?

Also we enter/exit scope **AFTER** we call `FindAlloc `
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/7bafca4e550d451925abfa2f0bc897d080cbbf35/src/pass/storage_rewrite.cc#L736

It makes more sense to me that we move enter/exit scope code right after:
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/7bafca4e550d451925abfa2f0bc897d080cbbf35/src/pass/storage_rewrite.cc#L693

After making the fixes, it does generate the expected IR. While 6 python tests failed in `test_pass_storage_rewrite.py`.  I'll dig, but want to check that I'm heading to the right direction @tqchen

Locally, here is the error message:

```bash
docker/bash.sh tvmai/ci-cpu
# inside the docker
./tests/task_rust.sh

error: failed to load source for a dependency on `bounded-spsc-queue`

Caused by:
  Unable to update registry `https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index`

Caused by:
  failed to open: /opt/rust/registry/index/github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823/.cargo-index-lock

Caused by:
  Permission denied (os error 13)
```

It could due to some permission problem in file creation. Again our docker mode was a bit weird in a sense that user who executes in the docker is not root. But the docker build phase is run as root. You can reproduce locally via ```docker/bash.sh``` script

@siju-samuel @junrushao1994 @MarisaKirisame welcome to review.
@tqchen @siju-samuel @junrushao1994 @MarisaKirisame welcome to review.

The original assumption was indeed that most memory allocation should appear in the outermost scope of the threading boundary. This is true and useful for most memory optimizations, as dynamic allocating and de-allocating is not good for performance and do not work for on-device memory.

Maybe in cases where there is dependent memory, we should either shoot an error, or relax the memory boundary to its maximum value then run the lifting, thoughts?

The reasoning was not about correctly implementing something, but more about if we can use the simplest method to guarantee the correct and efficient usage. The original decision on restricting allocation site is made with that reasoning.
LGTM

@anijain2305 could you try this case.
https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/simplify-if-stmt-within-for/830

more cases:
test_cce_loop_1: fail to partition
test_cce_loop_2: ok
test_cce_loop_3: fail to partition

```
import tvm

def test_cce_loop_1():
  ib = tvm.ir_builder.create()
  len = 112
  tile = 32
  loop = (len + tile - 1) // tile
  with ib.for_range(0, loop, 'i') as i:
    head = i * tile
    tail = tvm.select(head + tile > len, len, head + tile)
    ib.emit(tvm.call_extern('float32', "cce_intrisic", head, tail))

  stmt = ib.get()
  stmt = tvm.ir_pass.LoopPartition(stmt, True)
  stmt = tvm.ir_pass.Simplify(stmt)
  print stmt

def test_cce_loop_2():
  ib = tvm.ir_builder.create()
  len = 112
  tile = 32
  loop = (len + tile - 1) // tile
  with ib.for_range(0, loop, 'i') as i:
    head = i * tile
    with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(head + tile > len)):
      tail = len
      ib.emit(tvm.call_extern('float32', "cce_intrisic", head, tail))
    with ib.else_scope():
      tail = head + tile
      ib.emit(tvm.call_extern('float32', "cce_intrisic", head, tail))

  stmt = ib.get()
  stmt = tvm.ir_pass.LoopPartition(stmt, True)
  stmt = tvm.ir_pass.Simplify(stmt)
  print stmt

def test_cce_loop_3():
  ib = tvm.ir_builder.create()
  len = 112
  tile = 32
  loop = (len + tile - 1) // tile
  with ib.for_range(0, loop, 'i') as i:
    head = i * tile
    with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(head + tile > len)):
      tail = len
      with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(i > 0)):
        init = 0
        ib.emit(tvm.call_extern('float32', "cce_intrisic", head, tail, init))
      with ib.else_scope():
        init = 1
        ib.emit(tvm.call_extern('float32', "cce_intrisic", head, tail, init))
    with ib.else_scope():
      tail = head + tile
      with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(i > 0)):
        init = 0
        ib.emit(tvm.call_extern('float32', "cce_intrisic", head, tail, init))
      with ib.else_scope():
        init = 1
        ib.emit(tvm.call_extern('float32', "cce_intrisic", head, tail, init))

  stmt = ib.get()
  stmt = tvm.ir_pass.LoopPartition(stmt, True)
  stmt = tvm.ir_pass.Simplify(stmt)
  print stmt

if __name__ == "__main__":
  test_cce_loop_1()
  test_cce_loop_2()
  test_cce_loop_3()

```
LGTM

attempting where

@xqdan Thanks for providing the test cases. Current situation is 

1) https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/simplify-if-stmt-within-for/830 --> If you add ib.likely in the conditions, it gets partitioned. Currently, the loop partitioning only works for likely primitives.

2) cce_loop_1 --> select not supported for loop partitioning
3) cce_loop_2 --> Seems good
4) cce_loop_3 --> Will need to dig deeper. I think 2 conditions dependent on i back to back is throwing code off. 
~~~
  with ib.for_range(0, loop, 'i') as i:
    head = i * tile
    with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(head + tile > len)):
~~~

I agree that the name `where` sucks, but MATLAB and numpy seem to actually use that name since the beginning of time. If our target customers are machine learning engineers, it could be great because that is the way they think of things.

An absolutely perfect solution would be that we could introduce aliases of this operator, like `blend`, if you are interested.
Will rebase

Also realized that there is a problem with making the `fill_value` an attribute, as that now would mean that there is no data type to copy if the `dtype` attribute is left unspecified. I've left the code as it was but we can easily change it later
Will do
@junrushao1994 Thanks for the information. I will just keep the name for now.
Another question about `batch_norm`: The NNVM docs said that the default axis argument was 1. Was that 0-based or 1-based?

@MarisaKirisame The most straightforward way is to add another function in the python frontend, but call the exactly same `_make.where`...

_infer_out_shape may not help here !!

@srkreddy1238
Presently, if we load the TensorFlow networks in NNVM without adding shape information, the test fails with the following error: **Please freeze the graph with add_shapes=True**. This suggests that the attribute **_output_shapes** of an op/node derived using graph_def.node will always have the shape information. In this implementation under discussion, we use **_input_shapes** to look for the shape. We probably dont even require to infer the shapes. Is there a case where this assumption will fail?
Yes, as the ```_output_shapes``` via add_shapes may be incomplete.
I'm mistaken. There was no config.mk file as mentioned in the tutorial, so I was confused there. Sorry about that.

@junrushao1994 @MarisaKirisame Thanks for the thoughts. IMHO, it looks a little strange to me to have "two" operators doing the same thing. Between these two options, I think providing an alias frontend API would be more suitable since the users/customers mostly only take APIs. But I am open to any other inputs.

hi,
here's another case as bellow fail to partition, please consider:

import tvm 
  
def test():
    ib = tvm.ir_builder.create()
    loop1=4
    loop2=9998
    tile=39991
    with ib.for_range(0,loop2,'i') as i:
        with ib.for_range(0,loop1,'j') as j:
            head1 = i 
            head2 = j 
            with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(head1*loop1 < tile - head2)):
                with ib.if_scope(ib.likely(head1*loop1 < tile - head2)):
                    ib.emit(tvm.call_extern('float16',"cce_intrinsic",head1))
 
    stmt = ib.get()
    print stmt
    print "==="
    stmt = tvm.ir_pass.LoopPartition(stmt,True)
    print stmt
 
test()

Sorry I was not being clear, let us still keep AssertEQ as it could have special implementations, the other conditions can be redirected to Assert
@tqchen could you comment on the alias thing?

Some of them are certainly doable, we have already tried to speed up things by using code cache. 

I would say in the short term, it would be still better to wait for the CI to complete while trying to make sure things pass in the first place. It is much easier to waste a bit of time here to just make sure everything is correct. We could just be mindful and do code polishment before things are sent to CI
To keep things simple, let us just be consistent with numpy and do not introduce alias for now
